args:
After dispatching the demonic entities,

Nevin's team pools their information with Harle.

If the clues left behind by my impostor are to be believed,

it requires a mass human sacrifice with 666 victims.

They're going to butcher that many people

as part of some....some RITUAL?!

The fact such extreme measures are required is an indication of

just how powerful Satan's soul truly is.
And how do they plan on rounding up these 666 unfortunates?
I think I know just the event...

Grams will be flooded with people from the Northern Church.

more than enough to complete this grim task.

But the Auspecalia is only days away!

We have to warn them!

Easy there, Pinon. Think for a second.

Who exactly are you planning to warn?

Everyone traveling to Grams who is

about to be SLAUGHTERED, Nevin!

And considering the schedule, most of them are already in Grams by now.

Warning them won't help—we need to shut the festival down.

Ramiel?

Any progress on reaching our buddy Sandalphon?

No.

The effects of Basileus's device persist.
It is the same with me.

(Basileus knew this would happen.

But we have to do something...)

We're going to Grams.

I assume you're coming with us, Harle?

I wouldn't miss it for the world. After all,

the ones who humiliated me will be waiting there. Heh heh heh...

Then let's move out.

Everyone ready?

Curia of the Ilian Church of Grams

Holding Cells

You there. Guard. Put me through to the Aus...er, to Her Holiness the Pope.

I must speak with her about a matter.

She will listen if you give her the name"Alphir".

If you value your life and the lives of your loved ones, you will do this thing.

Pffft! You think I'm going to

fall for an obvious bluff like that?

If you think it a bluff, then by all means, do nothing.

Just don't blame me when tragedy befalls your household.

...Fine! But just a message, and only once.

Waste of time anyway—there's no way. Her Holiness will listen to some heretic.

I don't mean to doubt you, Regina,

but why would Origa give us the time of day?
Because I'm betting she hasn't forgotten.

More importantly, Ryszarda,

what of your Sigil connection to Rafael?

Nothing. I can't feel a thing—and I don't know

if this is something that'll get better non its own or not.

So you're in the same position we are.

Sadly, we can't hope to break out of here by force without the Sigil's strength.

Which means we're left counting on Faris and his plotting.

Uriel didn't say anything when you were captured, did he?

No. Well, other than he was sure Faris

would get passing marks.

Ever the doting father. Still, if they already had a plan in mind then,

it would be to... Yes, of course!

But in that case, I'd want a fallback—

or ideally two.

I don't know what the hell is going on here,

but...Regina, Her Holiness is asking for you!

Grams

Curia of the Ilian Church of Grams

You mustn't, Your Holiness!

That woman commands the apostles, which makes her chief among traitors!

I will not repeat myself, Cardinal.

Now stand down.

...Understood, Your Holiness.

But do not hesitate to call for me if anything untoward happens.

That nuisance has been sent packing.

If you've something to say to me, now is the time.

I'd hoped we could meet again under better circumstances,

but I'm glad to see you looking well regardless.

Then I'll be blunt: These accusations of betrayal are nothing but lies,

and I request our immediate release.

Denied.

I won't retract an order once given.

Add whatever conditions you must. Have us monitored if that helps.

I only ask that you allow us to investigate this matter and clear our names.

Denied.

You can wait in your cell until the Auspecalia is over. ...Was that all?

Nope! I have a mountain of things to talk about,

and I assume you feel the same since you agreed to see me.

I hoped we might have a proper talk

before I attended to my duties at the Auspecalia...Sister.

One day, I gained a sister.

She was much younger and not related by blood.

My parent married hers, and suddenly we were family.

At first, I wasn't sure how to approach her given the age gap,

but we were soon inseparable.

We may have been stepsisters,

but we were still as close as any blood siblings could be.

...Until the day everything changed.

Our village, Alphir, stood in the path of a raging war

and was burned to ash in a single night.

The heat of the fire. The burning in my throat.

The cries for help. The smell of seared flesh.

My happy life crumbled before my very eyes.

I'd held my sister's hand every day since we first met.

But on that day...I let go.

...And I have regretted it ever since.

Not a day goes by where I don't ask myself why I did it. How I COULD have done it.

I fled a war. I nearly starved to death in the lowest slum of Grams.

And yet all that time, you were the only thing in my mind.
How long I have wanted to apologize!

An apology is hardly necessary.

If anything, I'm grateful.

It is true my life changed when we parted. Days of crawling through the mud.

Drinking from puddles. Eating rotting carcasses...

And things did not get better even when I was taken in by the orphanage

or when my aptitude as an Auspex was discovered.

It was one horror after the next, and I wished for death more times than I know.

Yet here I am, still very much alive.

I survived agonizing training. Survived the viper's den of the other Auspex candidates.

And in the end, I claimed the title.

Now here I stand, Her Holiness the Pope.

And it is all thanks to you, dear sister.

That day you shook loose my hand,

you helped me realize somethingof paramount importance...
A person must reach out and claim happiness for themselves!

Thank you. Now I have nothing left unsaid.

I am fine on my own, and here our conversation will end.

You're right, Origa.

Everyone has to findtheir own happiness.

When I learned you'd become the Auspex, I also undertook training that nearly killed me—

and I did so in the hopes I might see you again.

My work earned me a place in the Canon high enough to enter the Curia, 

and eventually I was given command of the apostles.

Well, I suppose my natural affinity for the angels played a part in that,

so it feels strange to claim all the credit...
But working with the apostles under me taught me a new lesson...

We all must find our own happiness,

but that doesn't mean we have to do so without help.

Will you let me help you, Origa?

Will you let your sister help you?
Guard, return this woman to her cell.

No, wait! Just one more thing, Origa.

Do me this final kindness.

Will you return the tablet that was confiscated when I was brought in?

It's terribly boring in that cell.

Do you seek to mock Her Holiness?

She would never grant such a thing!

It holds all the records of an experiment I was conducting,

and I was interrupted at the most awkward and unsatisfying—
*sigh* It's fine. Give it to her.

Graht said it doesn't serve a purpose outside of magical analysis,

so I fail to see the harm.
As you command. Now move along, you!
I'm glad we were able to speak in the end, Sister.
Hmm. I had no idea that Origa and Regina were sisters.

Still, I can't have Origa swayed by paltry sentimentality,

so I'm afraid her dear sister will have to die.
Are you certain that's wise, Eminence?

If we kill her and are unable to ready a replacement who is compatible with Sandalphon's sigil,

it could mean losing an angel.

What use has the Church for angels anymore?

Now do as I command.
This the thing you were moaning about?

Yes, and thank you so very much!

...And that's fallback number two.
If we're done here, get back in your—
What? Hey! What are you doing?!

You met the Auspex's compassion with betrayal, knocked the guard unconscious,

and fled. ...Or so the story will go.

Here to kill me, are you?

On Graht's orders, no doubt.

That isn't for you to know.

Now, as a final act of piety, die quietly for the Church's glorious future.

Actually, I was just feeling a bit stiff, and a workout sounds nice.

So anyone who wants to be cut down, come at me!

content.content:
After dispatching the demonic entities, Nevin's team makes for Grams to report their discoveries.
Meanwhile, Regina asks her guard to deliver a message to Origa and secures an audience, but Graht learns that Regina is Origa's sister, he orders the former's assassination.
